Only limited by your imagination.

Been playing this game since 2015, you do everything from playing prop hunt with friends to playing as a Detective in 1980s New York.

And if something does not exist in Gmod, you can make it yourself.

Garry’s Mod is the game that answers the question: What if you could play with absolutely everything and completely ruin it for everyone else?

Imagine a world where you can build things, break things, and make even the simplest of tasks somehow end in disaster. Want to build a car? Great! Now, let's launch it into space by accident! Think you can create an epic roller coaster? Nope, it’s now a death trap that’s definitely not OSHA-approved.

The physics engine is a glorious mess—characters' limbs defy the laws of physics, and objects will float, bounce, or explode with no warning whatsoever. The AI? If you want to see your NPCs walk into walls or perform complex dances of incompetence, Garry’s Mod has you covered.

And don't even get me started on multiplayer. Sure, you can try to work together with friends on building something cool, but you’ll inevitably spend hours messing around with each other’s creations. That one friend who decides to fill an entire map with explosive barrels? Yeah, that’s probably you.

Garry’s Mod is the epitome of chaos and creativity. If you’ve ever wondered, What happens if I put a tank on top of a flying car? then this game will answer that question for you… and probably destroy your PC in the process.

Garry's Mod is the ultimate sandbox experience—pure, unrestricted creativity mixed with chaotic fun. With over 1000 hours in the game, I’ve seen everything from hilarious DarkRP shenanigans to mind-blowing custom game modes that push the Source engine to its limits.

The best part of Gmod is its modding community. Whether it was building on OG servers like CancerRP or running wild in TTT-Fun DarkRP, there was always something fresh to dive into. Lua scripting allowed for nearly limitless customization, making every server feel unique.

Of course, Gmod isn’t without flaws. The physics can be janky, and loading into certain servers can take forever thanks to massive addon lists. But despite that, it still holds up as one of the best multiplayer sandbox games ever made.

Even after 1000+ hours, it never truly gets old.
